message: Please welcome your host, Amit Bharma. Welcome to The Seen and the Unseen. Today's episode is on a chronic disease that is once again sweeping through India like an epidemic, farm loan waivers. My first guest today is Vivek Kaul, a columnist for Equity Master who has written the Easy Money Trilogy. Do check out his fine book, India's Big Government, which is on Amazon right now. My second guest is Kumar Anand, an economist based in Mumbai. Vivek and Kumar, welcome to the show. Thanks Amit. Thanks Amit. Kumar, I remember you once told me a fascinating story about your dad who works in a bank. Can you tell us about it again?

speaker: Guest 1
message: My dad is retired now, but yeah, the story goes back in 2008. So early 2008, this was just before Manmohan Singh government announced a farm loan waiver of about 60,000 crore, if I'm not mistaken. So my father, he was a bank manager for a regional rural bank in a small town in Bihar and as part of his day-to-day job, he has given and disbursed a lot of loans. And one particular kind of loan was something under which is disbursed to farmers called Kisan Credit Cards. So this is a small sum of money which is given to farmers to meet their daily production, you know, expenses. So it was a small sum of money for 50,000 rupees. So this guy who the money was given to, he comes to my father with 40,000 rupees with the intention of returning as a lump sum payment back to the bank and says that before depositing the money, he says to my dad that, sir, I have been listening to the stories, a lot of murmurs and chatter that there is going to be a farm loan waiver, you know, politicians are talking about it, probably something is going to come. And then my father convinces him that, you know, why you should still deposit because it was the job of my father to convince him and so that, you know, the banks continue to do good business. And overall, basically, he agrees and he deposits the money. And just about a few days later, Manmohan Singh government comes and announces the farm loan waiver. So a few days later, he comes back to see my dad in the bank and says, sir, my neighbor who has taken the loan with no intention of returning the money is now going to get the entire, you know, his loan waived off, while just because I made the mistake of being an honest borrower and paying back on time, I am stuck with getting no relief.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: So essentially what the farm loan waiver did was that farm loan waivers incentivize the dishonest people who don't mean to return and it punishes the honest people who are actually making an effort to return the money on time. And economists, of course, as you know, call this a moral hazard. The same principle, for example, applies to the bailouts of banks, big banks too big to fail that happened after the 2008 crisis, that if you know you're going to get bailed out, if you know you're going to get a waiver, then you don't have to behave responsibly because the consequences of that are not what they otherwise would be.
